attributes.Title: Spectroscopy Theory
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Chemistry
778
UMass Amherst
Microwave, infrared, Raman, visible and ultra-violet spectra and structure. Molecular geometry from rotational spectra, normal coordinate analysis, anharmonicity and dissociation, hindered rotors, crystals, intensities and charge flux, vibrational dichroism, non-linear inelastic light scattering. Prerequisite: CHEM 476 or equivalent.
Undergraduatess may register with a prerequisite of Chem 475 or Chem-Eng 475 or Physics 424, any with a grade of "B"  or higher.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
64165
Requisite: Microwave, infrared, Raman, visible and ultra-violet spectra and structure. Molecular geometry from rotational spectra, normal coordinate analysis, anharmonicity and dissociation, hindered rotors, crystals, intensities and charge flux, vibrational dichroism, non-linear inelastic light scattering. Prerequisite: CHEM 476 or equivalent.
Undergraduatess may register with a prerequisite of Chem 475 or Chem-Eng 475 or Physics 424, any with a grade of "B"  or higher.

attributes.Title: Ideas That Change the World
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201
UMass Amherst
In this seminar, students will examine texts and works of art that have profoundly shaped the world we live in. The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Statistical Physics
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Physics
602
UMass Amherst
Survey of thermodynamics. Boltzmann distribution, statistical interpretation of thermodynamics, Gibbsian ensembles and the method of Darwin, Fowler; quantum distributions and their applications, transport phenomena. Prerequisites:  PHYSICS 424, 601, 606 (the latter may be taken concurrently).
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

Requisite: Survey of thermodynamics. Boltzmann distribution, statistical interpretation of thermodynamics, Gibbsian ensembles and the method of Darwin, Fowler; quantum distributions and their applications, transport phenomena. Prerequisites:  PHYSICS 424, 601, 606 (the latter may be taken concurrently).

132

714

2016

114
UMass Amherst
Fundamentals of wave motion, vibration of strings, sound waves, resonance, harmonic analysis, sound intensity and the decibel, physics of the ear and theories of hearing, physics of speech, elementary properties of microphones and speakers. Prerequisite to COMM-DIS 311, 312. For communication disorders majors; open to others. Algebra skills needed.  (Gen.Ed. PS)

attributes.Title: Topics In Astrophysics
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Astronomy
330
UMass Amherst
Devoted each year to a particular topic or current research interest. Prerequisites: At least three semesters of physics, astronomy, or geology. Juniors and seniors only, or per instructors permission.
Prerequisites: 2 semesters of physics, 2 semesters of calculus, and an astronomy course at the 200 level or above.
ASTRON & PHYSICS majors and minors. Pre Req: 2 PHYSC&2 CALC&1 ASTR  Class begins Monday, September 8th. Questions should be directed to Houjun Mo at hjmo@astro.umass.edu.
----------------------
This semester's topic: Cosmology and Galaxy Formation.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Thermodynamics I
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Mechanical & Industrial Engrg
230
UMass Amherst
The fundamentals of the science of thermodynamics, control volume analysis of the conservation of mass and energy and the second law of thermodynamics, pure substance property relations, applications to refrigeration and power systems. Prerequisites: MATH 233, PHYSICS 151, 153 (MATH 233 and PHYSICS 151, 153 may be taken concurrently).
This course is open to MIE, ENGIN, EE, CS E, CH E, and CEE majors only. Pre Req: PHYSICS 151
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
558
UMass Amherst
Introduction to the properties of solids. Emphasis on the key role played by quantum mechanics in determining the electrical and thermal properties of metals, insulators, semiconductors, and magnets. For senior and graduate students in physics and astronomy, the physical sciences, and engineering. Prerequisites: PHYSICS 423 and 424.  (Planned for Spring)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Electron For Sci I
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Physics
531
UMass Amherst
Operation and use of the basic elements of modern electronics. Circuits designed and constructed in lab are               tested using modern instrumentation. Principles of analog circuit analysis, filters, diodes, transistors, operational          amplifiers, oscillators, power supplies, integrated circuits. A "hands-on" experience for those using electronic               equipment in research, testing, and analysis. Recommended for majors in all pure and applied sciences and as          preparation for digital electronics (Physics 532). Consent of instructor required. Prerequisite: PHYSICS 422.
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
31239
Requisite: Operation and use of the basic elements of modern electronics. Circuits designed and constructed in lab are               tested using modern instrumentation. Principles of analog circuit analysis, filters, diodes, transistors, operational          amplifiers, oscillators, power supplies, integrated circuits. A "hands-on" experience for those using electronic               equipment in research, testing, and analysis. Recommended for majors in all pure and applied sciences and as          preparation for digital electronics (Physics 532). Consent of instructor required. Prerequisite: PHYSICS 422.

attributes.Title: Conceptual Physics
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
100
UMass Amherst
The fundamental ideas of physics, a minimum of mathematics. Selected phenomena of everyday existence (motion, sound, electricity). Physics beyond the range of our senses, the realm of atoms and nuclei (quantum physics), the universe (cosmology), high speed phenomena (relativity). For nonscience majors. PHYSICS 103 serves as an optional laboratory to accompany this course. Prerequisite: Basic Math Skills (R1) proficiency, or equivalent.  (Gen.Ed. PS)
Cannot be taken for credit if already passed Physics 139
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61175
Requisite: The fundamental ideas of physics, a minimum of mathematics. Selected phenomena of everyday existence (motion, sound, electricity). Physics beyond the range of our senses, the realm of atoms and nuclei (quantum physics), the universe (cosmology), high speed phenomena (relativity). For nonscience majors. PHYSICS 103 serves as an optional laboratory to accompany this course. Prerequisite: Basic Math Skills (R1) proficiency, or equivalent.  (Gen.Ed. PS)

attributes.Title: Statics
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Civil & Environmental Engrg
240
UMass Amherst
To give students a fundamental understanding of basic principles in engineering mechanics.  Topics include force systems, the principle equilibrium of forces in two and three dimensional space, free-body diagram, centroid and moment of inertia of a solid body, etc.  The fundamental principles are applied to solve problems of civil engineering systems, such as beam, truss and frame. Prerequisite: MATH 132. Corequisites:  Physics 151 & 153.
Open to students in the College of Engineering. Pre Req: MATH 132
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
65912
65675
Requisite: To give students a fundamental understanding of basic principles in engineering mechanics.  Topics include force systems, the principle equilibrium of forces in two and three dimensional space, free-body diagram, centroid and moment of inertia of a solid body, etc.  The fundamental principles are applied to solve problems of civil engineering systems, such as beam, truss and frame. Prerequisite: MATH 132. Corequisites:  Physics 151 & 153.

Spring
2016
Mathematics
233
UMass Amherst
Techniques of calculus in two and three dimensions. Vectors, partial derivatives, multiple integrals, line integrals. Prerequisite: MATH 132, or 136. Students expected to have and use a Texas Instruments 89 Titanium Graphing Calculator. Honors section available.  (Gen.Ed. R2)
[Note: Because this course presupposes knowledge of basic math skills, it will satisfy the R1 requirement upon successful completion.]
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Biological Physics
attributes.Description:
Fall
2014
Physics
590K
UMass Amherst
This course, intended for students with a background in hysical or life science, will cover the following physical principles that apply to bilogical molecules and cells: Bownian motion, low Reynolds-number environments, forces relevant to cells and molecules, chemical potentials and free energies, as well as the basics of polymer physics.  These principles will be applied to enzymes as molecular machines, membranes, DNA, and RNA.  Also covered will be systems biology, which takes a different approach and tries to integrate the biological knowledge and to understand how the molecules act together within the network of interaction that makes up life.
PreReq:PHYS 132or152or182
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
71307

Sr KIN Majors KIN 270, Math & Physics w/ C-  Lab sections do not meet until the SECOND WEEK of classes.
If you cannot register through SPIRE and want to petition the instructor for enrollment in the course, please do the following: 
1) Go to the Kinesiology Office, 110 Totman Building, and pick-up a "Course Override Form." 
2) Fill out the form. 
3) Attach Unofficial Transcript to course override form and leave them both in the instructor's mailbox (also located in 110 Totman).

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
606
UMass Amherst
Electrostatic and magnetostatic fields in vacuum and material medium. Maxwell's equations, radiation, and special relativity. Covariant formulation of the field equations. Fields of a moving charge, motion of particles, radiation reaction, applications to physical phenomena as time permits. Prerequisites: PHYSICS 601, 605.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61332
Requisite: Electrostatic and magnetostatic fields in vacuum and material medium. Maxwell's equations, radiation, and special relativity. Covariant formulation of the field equations. Fields of a moving charge, motion of particles, radiation reaction, applications to physical phenomena as time permits. Prerequisites: PHYSICS 601, 605.

attributes.Title: Statistical Physics
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
423
UMass Amherst
Thermodynamic and statistical descriptions of many particle systems. The laws of thermodynamics. Entropy. Free energies. Macrostates and microstates. Canonical and microcanonical probability distributions. Phase transitions. Application to various systems, including classical and quantum gases, solids. Prerequisites: PHYSICS 284 and MATH 233, or consent of instructor.
An optional honors colloquium is available for this course.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61194
Requisite: Thermodynamic and statistical descriptions of many particle systems. The laws of thermodynamics. Entropy. Free energies. Macrostates and microstates. Canonical and microcanonical probability distributions. Phase transitions. Application to various systems, including classical and quantum gases, solids. Prerequisites: PHYSICS 284 and MATH 233, or consent of instructor.

attributes.Title: College Writing
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
English Writing Program
112
UMass Amherst
ENGLWRIT 112 (College Writing) is a first-year college-level writing course designed to help students expand their ability to write essays for academic, civic, and personal purposes and to develop their rhetorical awareness to write effectively in new social contexts. Based on the assumption that writing is a social activity, this course requires active engagement in the writing process, including pre-writing, peer review, revision, and editing. Students write five essays. This is the only course at UMass Amherst which satisfies the General Education College Writing (CW) requirement. Prerequisite: Placement into ENGLWRIT 112 through the Writing Placement Exam or a passing grade in ENGLWRIT 111 Basic Writing. May not be taken Pass/Fail.  (Gen.Ed. CW)
Prerequisite: ENGLWRIT 111 (or adequate performance on Writing Program placement test). Pre Req: ENGLWRIT 111
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61710
Requisite: ENGLWRIT 112 (College Writing) is a first-year college-level writing course designed to help students expand their ability to write essays for academic, civic, and personal purposes and to develop their rhetorical awareness to write effectively in new social contexts. Based on the assumption that writing is a social activity, this course requires active engagement in the writing process, including pre-writing, peer review, revision, and editing. Students write five essays. This is the only course at UMass Amherst which satisfies the General Education College Writing (CW) requirement. Prerequisite: Placement into ENGLWRIT 112 through the Writing Placement Exam or a passing grade in ENGLWRIT 111 Basic Writing. May not be taken Pass/Fail.  (Gen.Ed. CW)

attributes.Title: Modern Physics I
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
284
UMass Amherst
Fourth term of introductory Physics sequence. Survey of discoveries in physics in the 20th century; special relativity, prelude to quantum theory, principles of quantum mechanics with application to problems in one dimension. PHYSICS 284 and 424 constitute a full-year course in modern physics. Prerequisites: PHYSICS 181, 182, , or consent of instructor, MATH 233.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61184
Requisite: Fourth term of introductory Physics sequence. Survey of discoveries in physics in the 20th century; special relativity, prelude to quantum theory, principles of quantum mechanics with application to problems in one dimension. PHYSICS 284 and 424 constitute a full-year course in modern physics. Prerequisites: PHYSICS 181, 182, , or consent of instructor, MATH 233.

attributes.Title: Seeing The Light
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Physics
125
UMass Amherst
An introductory course on many aspects of light.   The course will include discussion and classroom demonstrations of  important aspects of light, shadows, reflection, light in nature (rainbows, mirages, etc.), lenses, image formation, reading glasses, photography (film, digital, f-numbers, etc.), the eye, perception, polarizing materials, where color comes from, color in nature, color mixing (lights and pigments), lasers, among other things.  The course is designed for anyone with an interest in the physical and natural worlds, but should be of particular interest to anyone who wants to better understand light, especially artists, photographers and those involved with lighting, e.g. theater lighting.  There will be many classroom demonstrations.  Lecture attendance will be important. Prerequisite: familiarity with elementary high school geometry and algebra is recommended.  (Gen.Ed. PS)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
31217
Requisite: An introductory course on many aspects of light.   The course will include discussion and classroom demonstrations of  important aspects of light, shadows, reflection, light in nature (rainbows, mirages, etc.), lenses, image formation, reading glasses, photography (film, digital, f-numbers, etc.), the eye, perception, polarizing materials, where color comes from, color in nature, color mixing (lights and pigments), lasers, among other things.  The course is designed for anyone with an interest in the physical and natural worlds, but should be of particular interest to anyone who wants to better understand light, especially artists, photographers and those involved with lighting, e.g. theater lighting.  There will be many classroom demonstrations.  Lecture attendance will be important. Prerequisite: familiarity with elementary high school geometry and algebra is recommended.  (Gen.Ed. PS)

2016

811

Fall
2015
Physics
116
UMass Amherst
The nature of space and time from the viewpoint of the special theory of relativity. Historical perspective. A variety of paradoxes and puzzles including the twin paradox. The speed of light as an upper limit. Muon decay. Photons. Basic high school algebra and geometry required.  (Gen.Ed. PS)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

ASTRON & PHYSICS majors and minors.   An optional honors colloquium is available for this course.
Restricted to Physics Majors and Astronomy Majors. All other majors need permission of Instructor

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Mathematics
131
UMass Amherst
Continuity, limits, and the derivative for algebraic, trigonometric, logarithmic, exponential, and inverse functions. Applications to physics, chemistry, and engineering. Students expected to have and use a Texas Instruments 89 Titanium Graphing Calculator. Prerequisites: high school algebra, plane geometry, trigonometry, and analytic geometry. Honors section available first semester.  (Gen.Ed. R2)
[Note: Because this course presupposes knowledge of basic math skills, it will satisfy the R1 requirement upon successful completion.]
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
131
UMass Amherst
Basic physical laws governing mechanics, heat, and sound; examples and applications from the biological sciences. Arithmetic, high school algebra, and basic trigonometry required. The recommended introductory physics course for majors in the biological sciences and related areas.  (Gen.Ed. PS)

attributes.Title: Big Bang To Black Hole
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
120
UMass Amherst
The great 20th-century revolutions in scientific thought: Einstein's Theory of Rel-ativity and Quantum Mechanics, at a level appropriate for non-science majors: Spacetime, length and time dilation, blackholes, big-bang cosmology; wave-particle duality, black hole evaporation. What constitutes a scientific theory. Prerequisite: Basic Math Skills (R1).  (Gen.Ed. PS)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61224
Requisite: The great 20th-century revolutions in scientific thought: Einstein's Theory of Rel-ativity and Quantum Mechanics, at a level appropriate for non-science majors: Spacetime, length and time dilation, blackholes, big-bang cosmology; wave-particle duality, black hole evaporation. What constitutes a scientific theory. Prerequisite: Basic Math Skills (R1).  (Gen.Ed. PS)

attributes.Title: Intr Solidstate Phys
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
715
UMass Amherst
Solids treated as translational symmetry structures, their effect in x-ray and particle scattering, and thermal and vibrational properties of solids. Binding energy of solids, electronics in periodic potentials, and formation of bands. The free electron model of metals. Prerequisite: PHYSICS 602, 614.
Pre Req: PHYSICS 614
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61267
Requisite: Solids treated as translational symmetry structures, their effect in x-ray and particle scattering, and thermal and vibrational properties of solids. Binding energy of solids, electronics in periodic potentials, and formation of bands. The free electron model of metals. Prerequisite: PHYSICS 602, 614.

attributes.Title: Physics Of Music
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Physics
115
UMass Amherst
Waves, the production and perception of sound, the physical basis of pitch, timbre, resonance, dissonance, and musical scales. Concepts applied to orchestral instruments and auditorium acoustics. Fundamentals of electronic sound reproduction and recording. Elementary algebra and powers of ten notation used.  (Gen.Ed. PS)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
31349

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
601

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Physics
151
UMass Amherst
Kinematics, vectors and scalars, Newton's laws of motion, work and energy, impulse and momentum. Conservation laws. Collisions, oscillations, rotational dynamics, waves and sound, fluids. Use of calculus in physics; problem-solving methods. Co-requisite: MATH 131.  (GenEd. PS)
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.

attributes.Title: Mech Analysis Human Motion
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Kinesiology
530
UMass Amherst
Application of principles of mechanics to the analysis of human motion.  Topics include: fundamentals of analysis, muscle torques, energetics, modelling. Prerequisites: MATH 127, 128; PHYSICS 131/133, 132/134; KIN (formerly Exercise Science)200 or 304 and 430 or 305.
Graduate and Senior Kinesiology majors only. KIN 430 or KIN Graduates
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Physics
568
UMass Amherst
Mathematical and conceptual aspects of the special and general theories of relativity.  Lorentz transformations, convariant formulation of the laws of nature.  The equivalence principle, curved spaces, solutions of the equations of relativity.  Prerequisite:  Physics 422.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Intro To Hearing Sci
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Communication Disorders
311
UMass Amherst
With lab. Time and frequency description of acoustic signals. Physiology of the peripheral and central auditory systems. Topics in psychoacoustics, including methodology, absolute and differential sensitivity, loudness, pitch, frequency and intensity resolution, and binaural hearing. Prerequisites: COMM-DIS 211, PHYSICS 114.
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

Prerequisites: COMM-DIS 211, PHYSICS 114.
